characters: OUTSIDE ON GROUNDS WITH JILL AND JOHNNY POPE
IN THE BATHROOM GEORGE AND JACKIE
LESTER, JACKIE AND GEORGE IN HALLWAY BY ELEVATOR
AT THE TOP OF THE DRIVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George on his bike threads through traffic on the Strip. this, we HEAR A FEW BARS of THE MAMAS AND THE PAPAS "Mond Monday." He pulls up to a signal beside a faded Eugene McCarthy billboard. Somebody HONKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, my sister's back from Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off. Winds through alleys and heads up the hill Jill's. It's a shortcut whose precision should make it obvious he's traveled it a number of times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George jumps off his bike and pounds on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JILL opens the door. She's shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a big canyon. (seeing she's upset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I'm sorry but I've gotta get back... just for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... every once in a while I just get the feeling something awful's going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... just... somebody's going to get me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill starts to cry. She ambles into the carport in her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had these dumb dreams lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're dumb, somebody... I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I can't remember. It was just in my dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill laughs. George comes over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's gonna get you. Now get inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll do what I tell you. Now get the fuck inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She backs inside. He moves in after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's gonna get you but me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaps after her and she screams, delighted. George cha her into the bedroom. Jill screams. He throws her on the and leaps on top of her, kissing her. She likes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, great, fantastic. Fantastic. Incredible. Incredible, really incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna open the shop, baby, I'm gonna open the shop. I'm getting it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now -- I'm at the epitome of my life. Right now I feel so good I'm afraid something's gonna happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets off the bed. Jill is fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a little kid, I used to want to go to Europe but right now wherever I am I'm gonna be in Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came from a meeting... I can't talk about it now, baby. But in a few days -- see I'm disgusted with my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said you were at the epitome of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, I am. But I've had it with chicks. They're like an occupational hazard. Six guys working for me... I'm gonna retire or settle down or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, baby -- I'm gonna retire with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her. They start rolling around on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I don't know. You're great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in the same house, you know, one house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George in bed, beginning to sleep. Hubert Humphrey expres opinion at his chances tomorrow on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you don't even like children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never even been around one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm around you and I like you, don't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not right now, I don't mean right now... but eventually...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie says she wouldn't bring children into this world. That it's hypocritical and overpopulated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEW BARS OF THE BEATLES AND "SGT. PEPPER" OVER George o bike whipping into bank parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sits talking, with MR. PETTIS, a bank vice preside He is perspiring a little. Somebody's breathing rather heavily. It's Mr. Pettis seated behind his desk now and opposite George. He's going over something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Mrs. Shumann called about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to school with her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you want to go in business for yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do know what money's like these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pettis grabs a sheet off his desk, one in plastic contain rates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, look at this. Nine, nine and three quarters -- that's our prime rate. And I'll tell you something else: the big boys are going for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, Mr. Roundy, we're paying six percent. Six percent. FHA's at eight and a half -- no, we won't be going back to the old days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got nothing to do with inflation. Rates, for example, rise independently of tight money if you look at interest curves carefully. Historically, that's always been true, though most people don't realize it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of references do you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hair, I do Barbara Rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean credit references, Mr. Roundy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill Haynes and JACKIE SHAWN, in mini skirts and boots, a having coffee at one of the interior decorator hangouts outdoors off Melrose in West Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAR HONKS. A Cadillac pulls up to the curb. Its occupan HONKS again, obviously trying to attract their attention. Jill starts to look over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're crazy. Don't look over, it's Lenny Silverman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real swinger. He's been trying to fuck me for about two hundred years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEONARD is now calling Jackie's name. Jackie can't avoid anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going for a pony ride at Kiddielands, want to come along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to meet a client... who're you dating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks off and spots a billboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, honey, don't be totally naive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, listen. He's a very good hairdresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill, I'm just trying to be helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spent three years with him. I just couldn't take it not knowing who was gonna pay the rent... his unemployment or mine. George was adorable but it drove me crackers. Now at least I'm comfortable. Lester does what he says he'll do. Maybe you're happy living like a gypsy. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is great but I know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face it, you can go around with cute guys and get hung up on their sexy bodies and things like that but sooner or later you've got to find somebody. Face it, time isn't on your side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the customers... that's my point. I'm the one they want. If I had my own shop, they'd leave and come to me. I have a lot of customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Roundy, why don't you make out a financial statement? It'll save us both some time. Miss Michaels here can show you... have it notarized and we'll see where we go from there. Miss Michaels, would you get me a couple of forms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pettis rises, shakes George's hand and disappears. George left with MISS MICHAELS, who has been more or less within earshot of the whole conversation. George is very upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill thumbs through a Life magazine with Eldridge Cleaver the cover, waiting for an interview in the outer office o the 9000 Building whose open window overlooks a smoggy ch of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's one of so many girls that at first she's not recognizable. All of them have composites which they carr leather folders. They eye each other uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the PRODUCER, Barry, and the director, JOHNNY PO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's where the pyramids are and we want real pyramids in the ad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... how long did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pope, chagrined, shoots Jill a look. He's trying to get h the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, is there somewhere else you'd rather go? Maybe we can change our location.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have something against traveling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unable to interpret Pope's looks to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, do you have something against us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Jill, you can say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm embarrassed to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is, too, and Pope can see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't misunderstand... I'd really like to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill is at the door. She turns back. To Pope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the shop on Brighton Way in Beverly Hills. A FEW BARS SIMON AND GARFUNKEL'S "SOUNDS OF SILENCE" covers George pulling up on his bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is empty of traffic except there are scores an scores of parked cars, a few parking lot attendants, and meter maids. George starts toward the shop. A pair of wom in colored smocks and huge curlers burst out of the shop. They look like Medusas. They hurtle down the sidewalk as they're running from something. Then they find their respective cars and begin pouring pennies into the meters. CLINK, BUZZ, CLINK, BUZZ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks glum. He's walking along the street. A GIRL stops him. She's driving by in a 3.4 Jag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, I reconciled with Ron, you know, the guy I divorced last summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, great. I hope you make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody HONKS in back of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have your number, stop by the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks after her, smiling. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large gilt mirror on one wall of the shop. It covers mo of the wall it leans against.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attractive young woman in her early thirties, everythi matching, a real French garden, leans forward INTO SHOT a looks at herself in the mirror. She studies her image carefully. She moves closer to it. She seems uncertain at first. Then as she looks her conviction grows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back to DENNIS LOLLY, her hairdresser. She take his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her other hand she touches her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think there's enough height? I mean do you think there's enough height?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she and Dennis look into the mirror at her together. Dennis toys with the calico scarf around his neck. Felici in far corner, waits defiantly. George spots her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, do you think there's enough height?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I didn't say a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you think? Is there enough height?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Dennis and Tina turn back to the mirror for further deliberation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, do you think there's too much height?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great. You don't know what happened, this girl she almost got--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about that girl, I don't care if she's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm perfectly calm, George, I'm simply saying you have no respect for me, that you're incapable of distinguishing between me and one of your average Hollywood... mummers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Numbers, and I don't need to place myself in that kind of position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just needed a wash and set, a wash and set, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, baby, I'm George and it needs to be cut. (to Felicia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't want to place you in that position either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I like myself far too much, far too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to place you in any position --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to be put in that kind of position...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have Mary wash you. Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- A brillo pad, I don't care, anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary has gone over to the shampoo stand above which are several photographs of models and one of a handsome young black Marine in fatigues. George has gone to pick up a ra changes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You takin' a lot of shit lately, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then again you ask for it -- you just like my Otis -- can't keep his hands outta ladies' hair either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That boy always does great. He's a corporal or a squad leader or something, just wrote me from some place called Kwang Due?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you don't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George winks at Mary, heads back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not used to that kind of treatment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been treated that way, and I'm not going to start now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I don't know, baby, I been cutting too much hair lately. I'm losing all my concepts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill has entered the shop. She approaches George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want me to go to Egypt for three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill stands there now, not knowing what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it go at the bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I talk to you for a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I wasn't sure if I could go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, great, listen, baby, I gotta get back, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but how did it go at the bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late, we're all backed up and you're supposed to go to Buffums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised you'd do the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't use that tone of voice with me... never mind, I'll take Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George turns back to Felicia as RICCI comes by. He's near tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what that Lillian Bercovici just did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touched it! Then she played in it and got it all into something else. Now I don't know what it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's waiting for George for sympathy. Jill steps away gathering patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't even stand to talk to her on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, Norman expects me to get in here, take care of all the customers and then do his show out in Norwalk. I gotta have my own shop, just out of self defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have this political thing tonight. Could you comb me out at the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm beginning to feel guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I ever do is play. I should be doing something to get my own shop open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shop. I think you're a good investment, and I don't mind telling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, listen, baby, I'm a star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, baby, say hello to Felicia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When can I talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, I'm in the middle of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know but this is important. I have to make a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, have they offered you the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I think they might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a second, I'll be right with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back to Felicia. Jill moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Just a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't offer you the job yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want your feelings about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, either we have a meaningful relationship or we don't, I've got to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, baby, can we talk about it later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I never know when you're working and when you're not working!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Felicia. As Jill leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fine. You really think I'd be a good investment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say so if I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I certainly wouldn't tell Lester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it or I wouldn't say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great. You look great, baby, great. Dennis, look at Felicia's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis stops. He's with the DESK GIRL. Both of them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill, in street, on verge of tears... moves to her car... gets in... sits for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George on bike pulls into office building. The MUSIC OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LESTER'S on the telephone, staring out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Kurt, I don't care where you have to go. I want Beluga Caviar there. Call Jurgenson's, call Chasen's... I don't care how much it costs... how much?... then spend it. Just make sure it's there. You've got all the money in the world to buy it. You understand? Just make sure it's there on the table tonight. (he hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to do everything yourself. You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Lester gives George a steely look. It covers his hair, his clothes. George is acutely uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felicia says you're a very good hairdresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says you're a fabulous hairdresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say it, she did. How'd you happen to get in that line of work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sort of knows what Lester's driving at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I went to beauty school... you know you go to beauty school... and you get your operator's license... and you graduate... and you're a hairdresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause. George hasn't told Lester what he wants to kn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the important thing is you're successful at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm better than the guy I work for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, George, I invest for a lot of people. I make a lot of money for them. More than they could do for themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a while that hurts... doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good you want to do something, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But personal services are not the kind of thing I usually get into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're a pain in the ass, there's no way of keeping track of anything. It's a cash business and you've got to watch your operators or they'll steal you blind, am I right or am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who needs that kind of aggravation? Who needs that kind of aggravation at my age? When I finish work I want to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bursts open. It's one of the SECRETARIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is right behind her. She bounces in, not seeing George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry but I need an extra garage key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Lester's presence she seems distinctly younger than sh did with Jill. She's startled when she sees George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? What do you need the key for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie continues to stare at George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man from Sloan's is coming. I called you about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you lose that key? Oh, George, this is uh Miss -- this is Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, I mean hello, we've met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, George is a wonderful hairdresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Who's been doing your hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to the blue'n gold barber shop in Westwood. The guy in the third chair's dynamite... nobody much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is going to open a shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, could you -- excuse us for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the office, shuts the door, leaving Jackie and Lester alone. Lester shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called to tell you I was sending one over but the line was busy, you're always on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think I was talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My secretary saw you with that boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever his name is, that actor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks for a moment as if she's going to get very emotional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve Slutes, and he's not a boy. (a touch bitter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve couldn't get arrested as an actor. He couldn't get arrested as a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you were talking to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ran into him at the 76 station on little Santa Monica, what was I supposed to do, hide in the ladies room? Yes, I was talking to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester's a little chagrined now but not much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm always on the phone because you never let me see anybody, I can't even bring my girlfriends over to the house because they might run into you. You're driving me up the wall, Lester. You're even jealous of the dogs. I mean I've gotta have somebody I can talk to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not jealous of the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks at him in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, Jackie, I'm not jealous of anybody, I just can't afford to get caught... off base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I can't talk to some broken down actor, what do you think, I'm going to tell him I'm screwing Lester Karpf!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: picking up the tail end of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks the room is soundproofed. Don't tell him it's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll have that awful construction crew back again, and they can never do anything right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very logical, it's the most logical thing in the world. You wouldn't feel this confined if we could go out with people and have dinner, and a little conversation and so forth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? How about starting with tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By her tone, Jackie indicates she's been saying all of th for months. Lester repeating it like it's just occurred t him genuinely upsets her. She's near tears and she's not kind of girl who cries easily. Lester's sensitive to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, I know it's rough but at this point -- my business involves handling money for some very touchy people, politics and so on... Felicia's at a very difficult period in her life... any divorce and settlement and so forth, my finances would have to be looked into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie knows what he's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... you do well for people, they don't ask you to stop. Nobody wants you to stop making money, doll, not even Uncle Sam. They all want their share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying about one thing, Lester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's said it provocatively and like the younger girl she be with him. Lester smiles. He's almost benign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her in his arms and she responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll work something out about tonight, I promise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Jackie and Lester emerge, distinctly subd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angie, give Miss Shawn a garage key for the Bowmont House, would you?

dialogues.text: Jill goes into the living room. George grabs her arm agai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go of me or I'll scream, I'll call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets go of her. The PHONE RINGS. Jill answers it. Her alters appreciably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi... listen, can I call you back?... Yes... no, everything's fine, really... bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told him I was here and he wanted to know if I was beating you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, did you get a job out of it at least?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like you to leave now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George doesn't move. Jill goes over and fishes into a tot bag by the wall. She returns with Felicia's missing earri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows, I'm sure you don't -- but if it'll help any, I found it in your bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George nods. Jill's anger is growing and her hurt is beginning to surface now. Tears start welling in her eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who else was there besides Jackie? Huh?... huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, don't do this. I do love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously there were others, weren't there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you wanna know for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to know, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to know while we were seeing each other... I just don't want girls looking at me and knowing and me not knowing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill is crying a little now and looks very vulnerable. Ge moves to her and tries to put his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, please don't... I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be a fool!... I want to look them in the eye and say, I know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she's backing up, he's trying to touch her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- it'll help me if you'll tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll know you've lied to me... all along. I'll know you're incapable of... love... that'll help me... not now, but eventually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been rising in him the last few exchanges. Now all George's restraints seem to leave him. He stops trying to touch her and stands his ground, exploding:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dumb cunt, everybody fucks everybody, grow up, for Christ's sakes. You're an antique, you know that? Look around you -- all of 'em, all these chicks they're all fucking, they're getting their hair done so they can go and fuck, that's what it's all about. Come into the shop tomorrow and I'll show you -- I fucked her, and her, and her, and her, and her -- I fucked 'em all!... That's what I do, I fuck. That's why I went to beauty school, to fuck. I can't help that, they're there and I do their hair and sometimes I fuck 'em. I stick it in and I pull it out and that's a fuck, it's not a crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George leans on a glass topped coffee table for support, even bothering to look at Jill. Jill has been pulled toge a little more by the speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... well I'm glad you told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His tone has indicated disbelief and disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am... I mean, you know, that's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... honest. At least you're honest with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all you've got to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- tell me something -- did you talk about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, if you keep this up I'm going to scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said you were a loser!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to cry again. George smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not a loser, baby, I just sort of break even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George turns and walks up the stairs and out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George shuffles up the steps to his front porch and into living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George finds himself facing Lester and two other MEN who like hoods. Lester sits in the chair George sat in the ot night. Before him is a bottle of J & B, a paper bucket fi with melting ice. The other men rise when George walks in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester, glass in hand, stares silently at George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Men walk toward George and pass him on either sid coming very close. Both of them are much bigger than Geor They stare through George as they pass him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George continues to stand there. Lester, drinking, contin to stare. Lester glances idly around the living room. The back to George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Lester... are you unhappy with me about something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm unhappy with you about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the men opens the door and peers through the scree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George site down. Lester has risen to his feet, a little unsteadily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, George, I want to hear it from you. Either you admit it, man to man, to my face or I'll have him pound it out of you, and he does a hell of a job, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna hear about it, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, have 'em put me away, or whatever you're gonna do, okay?... I'm too tired to lie, I'm too tired to tell the truth... I'm too tired for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna know your thinking, I wanna know how someone like you thinks. Did you think you could get away with it, did you think you could put something over on me? Does a guy like you get his kicks sneaking around behind people's backs and taking advantage of them? Maybe that's your idea of being anti Establishment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's got nothing to do with it... You're so beyond my comprehension I can't even discuss it with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't... just have 'em beat me up or whatever you're gonna do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not yet, not yet. You worry about it for a while, I've been worrying all night, now you can worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. Lester freshens his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it me, did you have something against me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, do you think I planned it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they have something against me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna hear it from you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... how am I gonna tell you what they have against you? I mean Jesus fucking Christ, they're women, aren't they? Have you ever listened to women talk, man? Have you? Well I do, I do 'til it's fucking coming out of my ears. I'm on my feet all day, every fucking day, listening to women talk and you know what they talk about, don't you? Being fucked up by some guy. That's all that's on their minds. I'm sure you've done something they could get pissed off about, what's that got to do with it? All women are pissed off, man, all of 'em. They fucking hate us! Don't you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester has listened to this with some alteration of his intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... yes, I follow your thinking on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're always trying to fuck them... they know it and they like it and they don't like it... that's just how it is... look, it's got nothing to do with you, man. It just happened. Felicia's got nothing to do but shop and get her hair done and she knows she's getting older... her daughter hates her, what's she going to do, go to PTA meetings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think Lorna hates her? I don't think she hates her. I mean she may resent her a little...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, are you kidding, man? She hates her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, why do you think that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck, Lester, how should I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. Lester goes to pour himself another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester gets up and goes to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have a clean glass in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to wash one out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns on the faucet in the kitchen. He brings the glas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, what a way to live. I never lived like this, not even when I was your age, not even when I never had a dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George takes the drink. Lester just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell of a way to treat a business partner, that's all I can say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you were never going to give me the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gonna give you the money. Probably I was. Shit, I don't know, I don't know anything anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester sits and stares into his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, you never know... you just never know... one minute you're here and the next... I mean a man at my age, how long have I got -- ten years? Five years? I wish I knew... what I was living for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You can lose it all; you can lose it all no matter who you are... I don't know, what's the point of having it all. Look at me. I don't have a goddam thing... the market's terrible right now, went down ten points last week, goddam Lyndon Johnson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah,, it goes up a little and then it goes down, maybe Nixon will do something. What's the difference, they're all a bunch of jerks. I wouldn't let 'em run my business, I can tell you that much. Not if I had any choice in the matter. (after a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to do with you. I don't know, I don't know what's right or wrong anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't either, Lester, I swear to you I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, how did that happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a whore, I go over there, have a few drinks and get my gun off. I'm through with her, she's nothing but a whore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, man, no. You can say everybody's a whore. She's okay. I mean Jackie'll fuck around but not that much. Somewhere she really likes you, Lester, and it's not just the bread. She's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester sits and thinks about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester goes to the door. He turns as if he'd just thought something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way, I think you oughta know -- Lorna thinks she's got the clap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the clap. That's what she thinks. But who knows -- I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George nods. Lester shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door and goes out. The two hoods are standin there. They look to Lester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go easy on him, he's a nice boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks shocked. Lester laughs, gives George a playf punch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just having a little fun, George... (to hoods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you later about the shop. I'm beat. God, I'm beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pulls up. He goes into the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is by the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devra, try Jackie Shawn will you? And if you don't reach her, keep trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Shumann and Mrs. Young are waiting. Mrs. Young is kind of p.o.'d.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devra, I asked you to call Jackie. Call her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's going to have to wash Mrs. Young. Mary's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Norman, I'm not the shampoo girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George starts to say something but he's tired. He goes to corner, slams his jacket down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George fiddles around with the shampoos and rinses, knock over one where the top was not on, and the shampoo spills over the table top and starts to drip on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, that fucking goddam Mary-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to look for a rag and sees that Mary, wearing a cloth coat is coming into the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary moves very slowly, George waits, hands on hips. It should almost be a little faggy, his petulance as if, inevitably some of the shop must rub off on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, where were you yesterday? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ran out on me and you left it like a goddamn pig pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Mary, are you drunk? Look, I've had a rough night, one of the roughest I've ever had, now I'm not in the mood for any sulking bullshit, what's wrong? Are you sick? Are you drunk? Can you work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points to his picture on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son Otis. He was killed in Vietnam. They done phoned me at the shop yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's suddenly very quiet. The SOUND of the SHAMPOO DRIPPI on the floor can be HEARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary starts to cry and like a little child buries her hea George's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you shouldn't talk to me like that no matter what, George... you know better...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you shouldn't do me like that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- why did you come in today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- left my bag, didn't have no money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on his cycle drives up Bowmont into Jackie's driveway. He car is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George jumps off his bike, fairly races to the door. It's open and he barges in. He's met by Jackie's Yorkies who b furiously, jumping up and down, nipping his pantlegs for attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie comes walking out. She's carrying a large cooking spoon and wears an apron over a travelling outfit, a pantsuit. She's wearing more makeup than usual. She stops when she sees George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is not prepared for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- yes, honey, you've got to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stares at her then walks past her into the living room. Bags are packed, a coat thrown over them. The wire kennel carrying cages for the Yorkies are beside the bags

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks into the kitchen where Jackie's been cooking some pasta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, we'll have to talk later --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about last night, it's okay, we'll talk when I get back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not okay, I mean we've got to talk now. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- either you leave or I leave because I don't want the two of us here when Lester arrives. I just don't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The level of her nervousness has just risen about fifty decibels. There's the SOUND of a CAR outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that she tosses the spoon onto an end table and rush out the door. George starts after her. The DRY CLEANER co to the door, stopping George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George has to fumble with Jackie's cleaning and keep the contained. He does, tosses the cleaning down and races outside to his bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he sees Jackie's car rounding the corner, going up the hi winding around the curves. George guns his bike and takes after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: almost sideswipes a car parked on a hairpin turn. Jackie' the curve above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: catches up with her, pulls even to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He threatens to run her into the curb. She stops the car sharply and jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've reached a cul de sac where there's a parched 'vie lot' not built on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow October weeds cover it and there's a huge televisi antenna in its center which sways slightly in an afternoo wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie has run onto the lot, then slows to a walk. She gr one of the rusty stays of the swaying antennas, stares do below her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her house can be seen from this angle, the Malone's truck just pulling away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then what are you trying to do-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to marry you. I want to take care of you and I want your children, and I want you to be my girl. That's all I want. That's all I want out of my life, and it's a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him in disbelief. She actually clutches her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't know if I'll ever make it. I mean I'm a fuckup, but I'll take care of you, I'll make you happy, I swear to God I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie doesn't answer. She slowly sinks to the ground. Ge sinks beside her. Her eyes are wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie... Jackie?... answer me, for God's sake, answer me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you knew how many times I wanted to hear you say that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's too late about it? Look, we're not dead, are we? That's the only thing that's too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester's left Felicia. He's taking me to Acapulco on the five o'clock flight. He's asked me to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? You don't love him, do you? Answer me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George now is very near tears himself. What he says now h has to force out of himself, as if it's the biggest secre holds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't trust... anyone... but you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George lets his head fall on her shoulder. She's kneeling supported by the television aerial, and George cries quie on her shoulder. She has her arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she's holding George, and looking down the hill, Leste silver Rolls pulls up. Lester gets out of the car, goes t the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't just let him stand by the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to... I've got to tell him where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- I've got to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up and hurries over to her car, starts it and go back down the hill. George sits under the television aeri and watches her car go down the hill, periodically flashi INTO VIEW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally she pulls up while Lester is pacing back and fort She hurries to him. He taxes her by the shoulders. They t for a moment. The discussion looks like Jackie is giving Lester directions. She glances uneasily up toward George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees that Lester and Jackie have their backs to him, h arm around her shoulder, hers around his waist. They're g through the front door.
